discourse_list.title: [Brainstorming] Product features & ideas for organic DAI growth

content.content: Bear markets are great time to build and brainstorm. The people that really care about the DAO are still here, not just for the speculative gains, but for the long-term vision. Hybrid crypto-backed vaults: Stacking coins The basic idea is to allow DAI borrowing by stacking ETH (Staked and unstaked) and wBTC into a single vault. Other potential combinations include stETH/ETH and wBTC/stETH.  Potential benefits include: more stable borrowing (<1 cross correlation between BTC/ETH aside from during drawdowns) and increased borrowing. Free-vault opening: Cover gas fees No-fee borrowing is pretty common in the real world nowadays as financial institutions have realized that giving up on “fees” at entry leads to longer-term benefits, in terms of net interest income. Gas fees have likely stopped a few from opening vaults in the past, and it would be great to hear from our growth/sales team if they have heard the same from prospects. This idea clicked recently, after joining Argent, I saw that the first crypto-purchase was fee free.  Screenshot_20220818-161930_Argent1080×1037 129 KB  Governance Polls: DAI gas fees Not sure that under our current governance structure this is possible, but paying gas fees in DAI would be a great way to attract more organic DAI holders. I believe this has a lot of potential internally and huge potential externally, especially if we are able to implement the ETH/DAI gas fees for other governance token polls. A first step could be to be able to pay gas in DAI, but its really just converted from the ETH equivalent, and MKR in the backend converts the DAI to ETH. If polls allowed voters the option to pay in ETH or DAI (ETH equivalent), imagine the growth impact that this would have to our organic DAI.
TRUEMAKER:  Free-vault opening: Cover gas fees   Great initiative. Giving up fees at entry level will attract more vault users.

I think this initiative can have more bang for the buck if it’s not offered to every wallet too. In general, for promos, I think it makes sense to provide them to a segment of customers only. In this case, it would probably be a segment of customers who left us for a competitor

lyt:  In general, for promos, I think it makes sense to provide them to a segment of customers only.   I wonder if in this instance it’s possible to test on a group of customers (existing and new) and see who it impacts the most?  If it’s the latter (which would be my hypothesis), I feel like you should give the fee break at entry to all customers, because the existing customers should get some benefit from already being on the platform.     TRUEMAKER:  but paying gas fees in DAI would be a great way to attract more organic DAI holders.   This I totally agree with.  I think humans have a mental model of preferring to pay in a stable value asset (DAI) than a variable value asset (ETH), because people that hold ETH might not want to sell because of potential value increases (even though there should be no difference rationally, because they can just convert between the two assets).

TRUEMAKER:  paying gas fees in DAI would be a great way to attract more organic DAI holders   I am inconclusive about whether it is possible to charge gas fees in DAI, but if so it is going to be a game changer.

When gas is cheap as it is now, I agree that it might make sense to offer this specific type of promo to new customers too. But when it starts to take $1k of fees to open a vault, we’d have to be very selective

Internally MKR could hold a small amount of ETH in its treasury so in the front end the voters would be asked to pay gas fees in DAI, which would go to the MKR SB, and in the backend MKR would pay in ETH on behalf of the voter (No impact to MKR balance sheet). This solution could be implemented in other protocols that would prefer a stablecoin gas payment method. As @Rachel_G pointed out, ETH holders are pickier when it comes to spending a token they are bullish on.

lyt:  But when it starts to take $1k of fees to open a vault, we’d have to be very selective   Good point. Would it be possible to cap fees paid? Or does block space get too expensive?     Rahii:  if so it is going to be a game changer   I would agree with that as well! Especially since DAI holders might be more willing to spend a currency that is pegged (not going up in value). Could be more revenue in exchange for the extra layer of coding!

Dilip:  Giving up fees at entry level will attract more vault users   I believe so too! Sponsoring initiation fees for longer term value would be great publicity too. Current market conditions are ripe for this kind of proposal (i.e. Low Gwei). Realistically covering gas fees of 10 - 100 DAI would be recovered within a 2 to 4 weeks (assuming a 50k loan at 3.5%). I can confidently assume that average client loan life is longer than 1 month. If the collateral gets liquidated, the liquidation fees would more than cover it as well.

Wish we could post GIFs here because I just want to react in a moving picture rather than words… It’s GREAT to read a super smart post like this with really fresh takes. This would permit canonical DAI to float and depeg from USD while still providing stability for end users (retail, institutional, OTC) via swaps markets that absorb the exchange risk. Writing as a community member, not an official ISCU communication.     ACREinvest:  There can be more than one DAI core product as @psychonaut recently suggested on Discord to accomplish the very big vision for organic DAI growth.    To be clear, the tension that I was initially trying to address is that some community members want DAI only backed by trustless on-chain bearer assets like ETH, stETH, and rETH. However, there is obviously not enough demand for leveraging long these assets to create enough DAI. So we could have it both ways. We could split the system into OnChainDAI only backed by trustless on-chain bearer assets and then use a PSM to allow OnChainDAI to be deposited to generate regular DAI. DAI would wrap like an onion around OnChainDAI. There would be OnChainMKR that only protects OnChainDAI and another PSM that can generate MKR from OnChainMKR. It’s not clear to me that splitting up the system like this is a good idea. It would nearly double the workload for PE or require the addition of an OnChainPE Core Unit to manage the OnChainDAI system. On the other hand, OnChainDAI would be easier to manage than DAI because it’s a simpler, more limited system. It’s not clear how the two surplus buffers should be managed. OnChainDAI should be isolated from DAI, but if there is a realized loss to OnChainDAI then it seems necessary for the DAI surplus buffer to recapitalize OnChainDAI. Splitting the system might also be a way to address the Tornado Cash debacle. Suppose regulators decide that DAI must have a way to lock and disable accounts. In theory, DAI could be redeployed with this ability, while OnChainDAI remains permissionless and uncensorable. Personally, I’d rather both flavors of DAI remain permissionless and uncensorable, but if regulators told us that we cannot access RWA then we’d be in a tough spot. So suppose we added an account disable capability to DAI. To account for the desirability of DAI over OnChainDAI, we could arrange for OnChainDAI to slowly lose value with a modest negative interest rate. Just spitballing here.

Thanks for fleshing that all out here! I wasn’t sure if it was being discussed on the Forum but it should be elevated in the broader conversation IMO. There’s no way to scale without some aspects of “Real World” compliance. But if we plan well and fix the organization’s capacity to carpe diem, I think a very pure, censorship resistant, open and permissionless currency can be ring-fenced to operate more “freely” while other parts of the project prepare to become the new backbone of all finance as we heard @yano speak about in the Meet Your Delegate call today (channeling @teej thought leadership in this).
